Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In some circumstances, courts may pierce the corporate veil under an "alter ego" theory where a parent-subsidiary, sister, or successor-employer relationship exists.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. Former employee alleged that employer would not have laid her off but for her age, as required to state disparate-treatment claim under ADEA.

Title: Brummett v. Bailey
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors set forth in Aronson v. Price, 644 N.E.2d 864, are not exclusive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was not warranted to find bar's owner and former owner personally liable for alleged assault on patron.

Title: Cyprus Amax Minerals Company v. TCI Pacific Communications, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, purposeful undercapitalization to avoid a potential judgment is the principal injustice that might lead a court to disregard the separateness of affiliated entities.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW  CERCLA. Company was liable for contribution under CERCLA based on operation of zinc smelter by subsidiary of company's predecessor.

Title: Lowery v. Noodle Life, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: When the elements of the doctrine are satisfied, the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil can be used to hold a family of corporations liable for the debts of each other.

Title: Micro Fines Recycling Owego LLC v. Ferrex Engineering, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the factors that may be relevant to a finding of complete domination over a corporation that supports piercing the corporate veil include: the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own; and other factors.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Buyer's injury was not caused by shareholder's threat to use its security interest to render corporation judgment-proof, precluding...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Smith v. A.O. Smith Corporation
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The distribution of related businesses across multiple corporate entities to secure liability protection and legal advantage is not by itself cause for piercing the corporate veil; instead, veil-piercing cases typically involve truly egregious misconduct where the corporate form is abused to such a degree that adherence to the corporate fiction under the circumstances would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Evidence. Former testimony hearsay exception was not applicable to testimony in prior litigation of former owner of company that was purchased by corporation.

Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors enumerated in Aronson v. Price, 644 N.E.2d 864, are not exclusive.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Soter Technologies, LLC v. IP Video Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to determine whether first requirement for alter ego liability, domination, has been met, following equitable factors are considered: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Trademark holder sufficiently alleged that use of domain name to redirect traffic to competitor's website constituted use in commerce of mark.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Creditor could not state a plausible alter ego claim to hold debtor liable under Louisiana law for the acts and/or omissions of related corporate entity, absent an allegation that debtor was shareholder of this related entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: TMX Finance, LLC v. Goldsmith
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is generally used for the purpose of piercing the corporate veil to hold an individual stockholder liable for debts incurred by the corporation; however, when the elements of the doctrine are satisfied, the doctrine can be used to hold a parent company liable for debts incurred by its wholly owned subsidiary, or to hold a family of corporations liable for the debts of each other.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Ousted LLC owners could bring direct action against line-of-credit guarantor and his businesses and were not limited to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: New South Communications, Inc. v. Houston Casualty Company
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida, Key West Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, each insured must establish its own rights to recovery under the policy, and it cannot rely on the rights of others; this is so even when the insureds are related corporate entities, since different corporations usually are distinct entities in law, and disregarding the separate existence of corporations is only justified where one of the corporations is a sham, or is used to perpetrate deception to defeat a public policy.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Property. Insured had no insurable interest in damaged properties and, thus, did not have standing to bring breach of contract action against insurer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: To warrant piecing the corporate veil, in addition to the requirement that the two companies operate as a single entity, Delaware law also requires that the corporate structure cause fraud or similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: A Delaware alter ego claim has two elements: (1) have the two companies functioned as a single entity and thus should be treated as such, and (2) has this corporate structure caused fraud, injustice, or unfairness.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the same facts used to show that the business entities operated as a single enterprise can lend the requisite fraud or inequity to warrant piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Former CEO's alter ego cause of action against parent company under Delaware law was property of subsidiary's bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Teran v. GB International, S.p.A.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Kansas law, as predicted by Court of Appeals, affiliate of majority owner of tractor supply company did not engage in any prior breach of shareholders agreement that provided affiliate with call right to managing director's shares of company after specified time period, and, thus, affiliate was not precluded from exercising its call right under agreement on such basis, since any breach that was alleged to have occurred was done by owner, not affiliate, and corporations in same corporate family are generally not liable for each other's conduct.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Shareholders agreement was not unconscionable, and, thus, affiliate of majority owner was not precluded from exercising its call right under agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Krausz Industries Ltd. v. Smith-Blair, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, separate identities of affiliated corporations may be disregarded upon establishment of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation was not affiliate's alter ego, and thus its North Carolina contacts could not be imputed to corporation for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Krausz Industries Ltd. v. Smith-Blair, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, in analyzing the control element for disregarding the separate identities of affiliated corporations, the court may consider factors such as inadequate capitalization, non-compliance with corporate formalities, complete domination and control, excessive fragmentation, non-payment of dividends, insolvency of the debtor corporation, siphoning of funds by the dominant shareholder, non-functioning of other officers or directors, and absence of corporate records.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation was not affiliate's alter ego, and thus its North Carolina contacts could not be imputed to corporation for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Krausz Industries Ltd. v. Smith-Blair, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, the instrumentality rule for disregarding the separate identities of affiliated corporations is an equitable doctrine; it is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative, but rather, it is a combination of factors which, when taken together with an element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that the corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of the dominant corporation.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation was not affiliate's alter ego, and thus its North Carolina contacts could not be imputed to corporation for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Krausz Industries Ltd. v. Smith-Blair, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, piercing the corporate veil is not dependent upon sharing of employees or direction of manufacturing operations of an affiliated entity; rather, it depends upon disregard of corporate formalities, commingling of accounts, sharing officers, and directing corporate or financial matters of the affiliated entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Jurisdiction. Chinese corporation was not affiliate's alter ego, and thus its North Carolina contacts could not be imputed to corporation for jurisdiction purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: TransPecos Banks v. Strobach
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: In order to show that a corporate affiliate received a direct personal benefit from a transaction involving the corporation, in determining whether a corporate affiliate used the corporation to perpetrate an actual fraud for her own direct personal benefit, as required to hold the affiliate personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the benefits received must relate to the allegedly fraudulent transaction itself, rather than to the more general personal benefits that the affiliate may have received from forming or otherwise generally using a corporation. Tex. Bus. Org. Code §§ 21.223(b), 21.224.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder did not use corporation to perpetrate an actual fraud in obtaining loan to refinance her father's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: TransPecos Banks v. Strobach
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Benefits to the corporation itself from the use of funds fraudulently obtained does not, standing alone, suggest any personal benefit from the funds, in determining whether a corporate affiliate used the corporation to perpetrate an actual fraud for her own direct personal benefit, as required to hold the affiliate personally liable for the debts of the corporation. Tex. Bus. Org. Code §§ 21.223(b), 21.224.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sole shareholder did not use corporation to perpetrate an actual fraud in obtaining loan to refinance her father's debts.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Continental Cas. Co. v. Symons
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, where a court is asked to decide whether two or more affiliated corporations should be treated as a single entity, the alter-ego analysis considers whether similar corporate names were used; there were common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce veil and hold shareholders liable for crop insurance business buyers' fraudulent transfer of resale proceeds to...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Berjac of Oregon
Court: United States District Court, D. Oregon.
Headnote: Under Oregon law, the "control" by another entity that must be shown in order to pierce the corporate veil is not simply potential control or control of general operations, but actual control over the specific conduct that led to the plaintiff's harm; therefore, even when affiliated corporations share directors, officers, and facilities, the control required to pierce the corporate veil is not necessarily present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee's fraudulent transfer claim against banks was not pleaded with sufficient particularity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Question under the mere department analysis is whether the allegedly controlled entity was a shell for the allegedly controlling party; it is not necessary that the entity was used to commit fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Jurisdiction. Bankruptcy court lacked personal jurisdiction over foreign participant in credit default swap agreements.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Vista Food Exchange, Inc. v. Champion Foodservice, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, company that entered putative oral exclusivity agreement for supply of food from wholesaler, could not be held liable for breach of contract, where wholesaler did not allege that entity directly breached the exclusivity agreement, but rather, related corporation submitted fraudulent invoices that caused entity to make payments to wholesaler for less than what was actually owed, which could not be imputed to company since corporation was a completely separate entity, and putative oral agreement would have been void under statute of frauds.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Comptroller of corporation was not a primary actor in relevant transactions for purposes of personal jurisdiction in New York.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Miller Parking Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a claimant corporation or shareholder cannot sue an entity that the claimant wholly owns or is owned by on the theory that the entity is the claimant's own alter ego.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Bankruptcy trustee could not file claim in different case on behalf of estate's creditors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Lee v. Certainteed Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, the facts that corporations have common officers, occupy common offices, and to a certain extent transact business for each other do not make the one corporation liable for the action of the other, except upon established legal principles.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Plastic manufacturer could not be held liable for pipe manufacturer's alleged negligence involving asbestos through joint enterprise theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Stewart v. Screen Gems–EMI Music, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: To demonstrate requisite commingling of assets, as the first unity of interest factor to determine, under California law, whether to apply alter ego liability, the plaintiff must present evidence showing that the related companies transfer assets among themselves for no ascertainable reason.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Songwriter's widow plausibly alleged that publisher and affiliates were single enterprise for purposes of her claim for breach of royalty contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Nature's Plus Nordic A/S v. Natural Organics, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the fact of corporate affiliation does not give an entity the right to bring a suit in its own name to remedy an injury to an affiliate.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Distributor did not materially breach the distribution contract's minimal sales requirement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re SK Foods, LP
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California, Sacramento Division.
Headnote: Under California law, sister entities may be determined to be alter egos if the entities are so organized or controlled as to make one entity merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of another.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Substantive consolidation of related entities with Chapter 11 debtors' estates was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re SK Foods, LP
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. California, Sacramento Division.
Headnote: Under California law, related entities were alter egos of corporation and limited partnership, where owners of corporation and partnership, as well as related entities, shared common management under ultimate control of single individual, related entities were undercapitalized, related entities did business almost exclusively with, and shared assets with, corporation and partnership and other affiliated entities, corporation and partnership essentially served as "bank" for related entities and more than $205,000,000 was transferred back and forth between them, and controlling individual disregarded entities' separateness, treated partnership's assets as if they were his own, and diverted assets of entities to shield them from creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Substantive consolidation of related entities with Chapter 11 debtors' estates was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Appalachian Fuels, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Appellate Panel of the Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under West Virginia law, separate entities of two affiliated, or sister, corporations owned by the same party or parent corporation may be disregarded if other prerequisites for veil-piercing are met.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Joint administration of Chapter 11 cases did not alter any substantive rights.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Tyson Fresh Meats, Inc. v. Lauer Ltd., L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Iowa, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Nebraska law, though a third party entity may be held liable for the actions of a sibling entity, the test for determining whether such liability lies has not been developed.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing LLC's corporate veil, so as to obtain personal jurisdiction over its members, was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Archdiocese of Milwaukee
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Corporate form generally is respected, and corporations are not liable for the debts of their shareholders or affiliates.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Case Administration. Committee failed to state colorable claim for substantive consolidation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: All Energy Corp. v. Energetix, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Iowa, Central Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, an "affiliate," for purposes of contractual liability, is generally defined as any corporation or business association which, directly or indirectly, is controlled by, is in control of, or is under common control with the corporation or business association entering into the contract.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Joint Ventures. Non-signatory to joint venture was bound by the agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Shearrow v. Easton Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: One circumstance in which a corporate affiliate of an employer corporation may be a proper defendant in a Title VII action is when piercing the corporate veil of the affiliate is appropriate because corporate formalities have been ignored and the actions of one company can accrue to another. Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 703(a), 704(a), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e–2(a), 2000e–3(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's corporate affiliates were not proper defendants in a former employee's Title VII action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Shearrow v. Easton Enterprises, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil of an affiliate corporation, a Title VII plaintiff must show (1) such unity of interest and ownership between the affiliate and the employer that separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice. Civil Rights Act of 1964, §§ 703(a), 704(a), 42 U.S.C.A. §§ 2000e–2(a), 2000e–3(a).
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Employer's corporate affiliates were not proper defendants in a former employee's Title VII action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Lianyungang FirstDart Tackle Co., Ltd. v. DSM Dyneema B.V.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, absent special circumstances allowing piercing of the corporate veil, an affiliated corporation is not liable for the alleged statutory violations of its sister corporation.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Advertising. Netherlands corporation was not subject to personal jurisdiction for Lanham Act false advertising lawsuit.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Burchinal v. PJ Trailers-Seminole Management Co., LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Texarkana.
Headnote: Creation of affiliated corporations to limit liability while pursuing common goals lies firmly within the law and is commonplace, and corporations are not held liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or injustice and inequity.
Document Preview: TORTS - Limitations. Limitations period for negligence claim was not tolled based on misidentification.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Winter-Wolff Intern., Inc. v. Alcan Packaging Food and Tobacco Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, two manufacturers of food packaging which were affiliates under same parent corporation were not in a principal agent relationship, even though the two affiliates had integrated their sales and marketing functions, since neither manufacturer exercised control over the other's production of products, and neither was contractually liable for the acts of the other.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Manufacturer did not breach covenant of good faith and fair dealing in contract with sales agent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois law endorses corporate-veil piercing to avoid unfair enrichment, to avoid permitting the creator of a corporate liability and cause of the corporation's inability to meet that liability to escape responsibility, and to avoid allowing a corporation to keep assets in a liability-free corporation while placing liabilities on an asset-free corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Domination and control of five corporations by their principal, who was their sole shareholder, officer, and director, was sufficient, under New York law, to satisfy domination prong of test for piercing of the corporate veil; corporations failed to exercise even most basic corporate formalities, corporations were inadequately capitalized and likely insolvent at all times, principal's system of using his wife's credit for corporate purposes and repaying her from corporate funds appeared to be for his benefit, principal, through his domination and control, created network of entities that were not intended to be independent profit centers, and principal promised to pay creditors seeking to pierce the corporate veil the debts owed by corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re Refco Inc. Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in considering whether a corporation exercised complete domination over a related entity, so that corporate veil may be pierced, courts consider such factors as: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms' length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: TORTS - RICO. Hedge fund failed to state claim against its administrator under New Jersey Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (NJRICO).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: Fischer Inv. Capital, Inc. v. Catawba Development Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Under the "instrumentality rule" for disregarding the corporate entity or piercing the corporate veil, a corporation which exercises actual control over another, operating the latter as a mere instrumentality or tool, is liable for the torts of the corporation thus controlled; in such instances, the separate identities of parent and subsidiary or affiliated corporations may be disregarded.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lender sufficiently alleged claim to pierce corporate veil of corporation of which guarantor was majority shareholder.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >
Title: In re DBSD North America, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Unless common law rule is changed by statute, corporate parents, subsidiaries or sister corporations are not liable on obligations of other separate entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Court would not decline to resolve claims objections under doctrine of primary jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1052 Related corporations in general >

Headnote: The doctrine of limited liability ordinarily insulates a corporation from the tort or other liabilities of its affiliates.

Headnote: Under Illinois law, claim for alter ego is one to disregard separate corporate identities of related corporate entities because one entity is so controlled and its affairs are so conducted that it is mere instrumentality of another.

Title: In re Alstom SA

Headnote: Factors to be considered in the determination of control or domination sufficient to pierce the veil under New York law include, among other things: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; * * * (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; and (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently stated veil-piercing theory of liability against corporate parent on control person claim.

Title: Pfizer Inc. v. Synthon Holding, B.V.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, instrumentality rule governing disregard of corporate form of corporation operating as mere instrumentality of affiliate applies when there is evidence of common ownership and actual working control, taken together with other factors suggesting domination of finances, policy, or business practice, such as undercapitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, and insolvency, but it is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative; rather, court looks to combination of factors which, when taken together with element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of dominant corporation.

Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Among factors that Louisiana courts consider in deciding whether liability may be imposed on a "single business enterprise" theory are presence or absence of the following: (1) identity or substantial identity of ownership; (2) common officers or directors; (3) unified administrative control; (4) directors and officers who act independently in interest of that one corporation; (5) intercorporate financing; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) one corporation's involvement in incorporation of another affiliate; (8) payment by one corporation of salaries and other expenses or losses of another; (9) fact that one corporation receives no business except that provided by affiliate; (10) one corporation's use of property of another as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees or offices; (13) centralized accounting; and (14) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Harrison v. Soroof International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to assess whether two entities function as one for purposes of the alter ego analysis, Delaware law asks courts to consider a number of factors about the parent and subsidiary companies, and their relationship to each other, including: (1) whether the company, i.e., the subsidiary was adequately capitalized for the undertaking; (2) whether the company was solvent; (3) whether corporate formalities were observed; (4) whether the dominant shareholder, i.e., the asserted alter ego of the company in question, siphoned company funds; and (5) whether, in general, the company simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.

Title: Pertuis v. Front Roe Restaurants, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of South Carolina.
Headnote: Under the single business enterprise theory, corporations are not liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or "injustice and inequity," meaning not just a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror, but rather, fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.

Title: Overton v. Art Finance Partners LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In assessing the first requirement to pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, whether the challenged entities operate as a single economic entity, courts consider: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a facade for the dominant shareholder.

Title: Andretti Sports Marketing Louisiana, LLC v. Nola Motorsports Host Committee, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Non-dispositive factors used to determine whether a group of entities constitute a single business enterprise under Louisiana law are: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Sports marketing company failed to plead that corporation and LLC involved in auto race were a single business enterprise.

Title: In re GGW Brands, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, Los Angeles Division.
Headnote: "Single business enterprise" doctrine, as applied by California courts, allows courts to disregard corporate form in order to hold one corporation liable for debts of another, affiliated corporation when the latter is so organized and controlled, and its affairs are so conducted, as to make it merely an instrumentality, agency, conduit, or adjunct of the first corporation.

Title: In re GGW Brands, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, Los Angeles Division.
Headnote: Under California law, party seeking determination that two or more corporations are a "single business enterprise" must demonstrate: (1) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate corporate personalities are merged, so that one corporation is mere adjunct of another or that the two companies form single enterprise, and (2) that inequity will result if the acts in question are treated as those of one corporation alone.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. That assignment was effected with actual fraudulent intent could be inferred from badges.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re GGW Brands, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, C.D. California, Los Angeles Division.
Headnote: Under California law, courts may consider several factors in deciding whether two or more corporations should be treated as "single business enterprise," including: (1) commingling of funds and assets of entities; (2) treatment by individual of the assets of entities as his own; (3) identical equitable ownership in the entities and employment of same workers and/or attorney, and (4) a diversion of assets from one entity to another to the detriment of creditors.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. That assignment was effected with actual fraudulent intent could be inferred from badges.

Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Choice-of-law rules applicable to claims to pierce the corporate veil applied to allegations asserted in support of claim under Louisiana's single business enterprise doctrine, even though that doctrine arose in different context and required application of different test, given that doctrine was grounded on same policies and doctrinal underpinnings as traditional veil-piercing theories, applying same choice-of-law rules was consistent with rationale for applying law of state of formation to veil-piercing claims, and effect of single enterprise determination was the same as determination of liability under alter ego doctrine.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Gulf Fleet Holdings, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana, Lafayette Division.
Headnote: Under test for alter ego liability under Delaware law, factors relevant to whether one or more companies constitute a single economic entity include (1) undercapitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) non-payment of dividends, (4) the insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time, (5) siphoning of the corporation's funds by the dominant stockholder, (6) absence of corporate records, and (7) the fact that the corporation is merely a facade for the operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee did not adequately allege claim to avoid repayment of insider's $4,000,000 loan as constructive fraudulent transfer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Reed v. Reid
Court: Supreme Court of Indiana.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce corporate veil, a court may disregard the separateness of affiliated corporate entities when they are not operated separately, but rather are managed as one enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice or to permit one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise; these single business enterprise corporations may be identified by characteristics such as the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Representation that allegedly hazardous waste to be dumped on landowner's property was clean fill could support fraud claim.

Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: "Single employer doctrine" is exception to doctrine of limited liability in corporate law, which allows corporate entities to escape liability for acts of separate, related entity; only in particularly exceptional instances will employees of one entity be treated as employees of a separate, yet related, entity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Ferrara v. Oakfield Leasing Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: In the Second Circuit criteria in analyzing "interrelation of operations" between separate corporate entities for purpose of determining single employer status are (1) involvement in daily production, distribution, marketing, and advertising decisions, (2) sharing of employees, services, records, and equipment, (3) commingling of bank accounts, inventories, and lines of credit, (4) maintenance of corporate records, and (5) preparing and filing of tax returns.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Attorney Fees. Time sheets in ERISA action for delinquent contributions were sufficiently detailed, but rates charged were not all reasonable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Chinese Manufactured Drywall Products Liability Litigation
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the factors to be considered to determine whether one entity is an alter ego of another, or whether two entities are a single business enterprise, are similar, and include but are not limited to: (1) common ownership; (2) common directors and officers; (3) common employees; (4) common offices; (5) unified administrative control; (6) similar or supplementary business functions; (7) one corporation financing the other; (8) inadequate capitalization; (9) one corporation's creation of the other; (10) one corporation paying the salaries, expenses, or losses of the other corporation; (11) one corporation receiving no business other than that given to it by the affiliated corporation; (12) shared property; (13) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (14) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfer of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Chinese manufacturer's wholly-owned subsidiary operated as alter ego or agent.

Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, when analyzing the domination and control element, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether the capitalization is adequate; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.

Title: Fendi Adele S.R.L. v. Filene's Basement, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors considered in determining whether a subsidiary and parent operate as a single economic entity for purposes of alter ego claim under Delaware law are: whether the corporation was adequately capitalized for the corporate undertaking; whether the corporation was solvent; whether dividends were paid, corporate records kept, officers and directors functioned properly, and other corporate formalities were observed; whether the dominant shareholder siphoned corporate funds; and whether, in general, the corporation simply functioned as a façade for the dominant shareholder.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS - Dilution. Retailer was liable for trademark dilution under federal and New York law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when two or more corporations constitute a single business enterprise (SBE), a court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations in order to protect against public inconvenience, wrongs, fraud, or crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: A "single business enterprise" (SBE) occurs, under Louisiana law, when a corporation is found to be the alter ego, agent, tool or instrumentality of another corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil piercing cases require consideration of four or five primary factors, and then an inquiry into the totality of the circumstances; single business enterprise (SBE) theory, on the other hand, uses an eighteen-factor test, in which no factor is dispositive, before considering the totality of the circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the eighteen factors a court must look at in determining whether to apply single business enterprise (SBE) theory to fuse either affiliated or unaffiliated corporations for jurisdictional purposes include: whether one corporation has sufficient ownership interest in another to give it actual working control, whether common directors or officers exist, whether a unified administrative control apparatus is present, whether the business functions of the companies are similar or supplementary, whether the directors of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation or instead in the interest of another corporation, whether one corporation finances or pays the salaries and expenses of another corporation, whether one corporation is inadequately capitalized or receives no business other than that given to it by another corporation, whether a corporation uses the property of another corporation as its own, complies with corporate formalities, or keeps common employees or offices with another corporation, and whether financial transactions suggest that two companies that are separate in form are in fact a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, single business enterprise (SBE) theory is not restricted to jurisdictional analysis; it is also a vehicle for holding a group of affiliated entities responsible for the obligations of one of the entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when a group of corporations integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose and do not operate as separate entities, each affiliated corporation may be held liable under single business enterprise (SBE) theory for debts incurred in pursuit of the general business purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, the degree of discretion demonstrated by the allegedly dominated corporation, whether dealings between the entities are at arm's length, whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and the payment or guaranty of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts look to several non-exclusive factors to determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, courts consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) intermingling of property between alleged dominator and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: R.F.M.A.S., Inc. v. Mimi So
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To succeed on an "alter ego" claim under Delaware law, and permit piercing the corporate veil of a company to assert liability, plaintiff must show that the two corporations operated as a single economic entity and that there is an overall element of injustice or unfairness present.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Art and Architecture. Competitors did not directly infringe owner's copyright to pieces of jewelry.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Commodity Futures. Market manipulation claim under Commodity Exchange Act was not stated against CEO of investment advisory company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is the alter ego of another, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil, a court considers the following factors, among others: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm"s length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner asserted valid maritime claim against guarantor of charter contracts, supporting attachment of $20,457,047.72.

Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce a corporate veil based on allegations of alter ego liability, courts may consider the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Budisukma Permai SDN BHD v. N.M.K. Products & Agencies Lanka (Private) Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although guiding principle for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is achieving an equitable result, relevant factors in evaluating sufficiency of veil-piercing claim include (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms-length, (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Attachment and Garnishment. Plaintiff need only make prima facie showing of alter ego liability to avoid vacatur of maritime attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re LMcD, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Under "single entity" or "enterprise" theory of liability, two or more corporations are treated as one when the following circumstances exist: identity of ownership, unified administrative control, similar or supplementary business functions, involuntary creditors, and insolvency of corporation against which claim lies.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Veil could not be pierced based on possible undercapitalization of LLC or mere confusion of identities.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether complete domination exists, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego, rather than single business enterprise, is the proper description for piercing the corporate veil. V.A.T.S. Bus.Corp.Act, art. 2.21(A)(2).
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Title: Wooley v. Lucksinger
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the "single business enterprise" theory is an equitable doctrine used to disregard the separate existence of corporations when the corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose.
Document Preview: HEALTH - HMOs. Seller and buyer of health maintenance organization did not operate as single business enterprise prior to or after sale.

Title: ASARCO LLC v. Americas Mining Corp.

Title: NetJets Aviation, Inc. v. LHC Communications, LLC

Title: Academy of Skills & Knowledge, Inc. v. Charter Schools, USA, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: The single business enterprise doctrine is not synonymous with the doctrine of alter ego; although the alter ego doctrine and the single business enterprise doctrine are both based on principles of equity, an important distinction is that the alter ego doctrine generally involves proof of fraud, whereas no proof of fraud is required under the single business enterprise doctrine.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Charter school's negligence claims were barred by the economic loss rule.

Headnote: The single business enterprise doctrine does not exist under Texas law.

Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the "single business enterprise" theory of corporate disregard, which is similar in purpose to, but is not considered synonymous with, the alter ego strand, is an equitable doctrine applied to reflect partnership-type liability principles when corporations integrate their resources and operations to achieve a common business purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, pursuant to the single business enterprise theory of corporate disregard, when corporations are not operated as separate entities but, rather, integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in the pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re JNS Aviation, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Amarillo Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, as opposed to "piercing" through the corporate shield to hold a shareholder or perhaps another affiliated company liable, the single business enterprise doctrine of corporate disregard recognizes the corporate shields of the two companies, but treats the two as partners given their common business purpose and thereby subjects each "partner" to the liabilities of the "partnership" formed by their relationship.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor could pierce debtor-LLC's veil so as to hold nondebtor owners liable for default judgment.

Title: Acceptance Indem. Ins. Co. v. Maltez
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the single business enterprise theory is an equitable doctrine used to disregard the separate existence of corporations when the corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose; its purpose, like the alter ego theory and other doctrines designed to pierce the corporate veil, is to prevent an inequitable result.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Whether insured was injured employee's employer for purposes of a coverage exclusion was a triable fact issue.

Title: Asshauer v. Glimcher Realty Trust

Headnote: The factors to consider in determining whether separate corporations should be treated as one enterprise include: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
