Title: Southern Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Louisiana law does not require the corporation to be insolvent before the single business enterprise theory becomes applicable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under single business enterprise theory, affiliated corporations could be liable for acts of separate corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Southern Capitol Enterprises, Inc. v. Conseco Services, L.L.C.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, a fundamental principle supporting the single business enterprise theory is that a corporation that is not directly involved in the dispute should not be permitted to escape liability simply because of business fragmentation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Under single business enterprise theory, affiliated corporations could be liable for acts of separate corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Mosqueda v. G & H Diversified Mfg., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Under the single business enterprise doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, each constituent corporation may be liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Manufacturer was allowed to invoke exclusive remedy provision in personal injury action by temporary worker.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Ark-La-Tex Timber Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, in some situations the corporate entity may be disregarded to impose liability upon: (1) a shareholder of the juridical person, that is, "piercing the corporate veil," or (2) an affiliate of the juridical person, that is, "single business enterprise."
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Bank had to return windfall that it received as part of erroneous disbursement of auction proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Ark-La-Tex Timber Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, when a group of affiliated corporations constitutes a single business enterprise, a court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations for the purpose of preventing fraud or achieving equity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Bank had to return windfall that it received as part of erroneous disbursement of auction proceeds.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Formosa Plastics Corp., USA v. Kajima Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether separate corporations should be treated as one enterprise under the single business enterprise theory include: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Experts. Expert was not disqualified in fraud action on basis of colleague's prior consultation with opposing party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Scully's Aluminum Crafts, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana's single business enterprise doctrine, court may disregard the concept of corporate separateness and extend liability to each of the affiliated corporations, for purpose of preventing fraud or achieving equity when court has found that group of affiliated corporations constitutes a single business enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Trustee could not hold new corporations liable for debtor-corporation's debts on theory of successor liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Verestar, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, plaintiff must satisfy a two-part test to succeed on a claim for alter ego liability: (1) that the parent and the subsidiary operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Committee stated claims for constructive fraudulent transfers, but not actual fraudulent transfers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Garden Ridge Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Texas law recognizes "single business enterprise" doctrine to prevent entity from relying on corporate form to evade an existing debt or legal obligation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Former employee of one debtor could not engage in triangular setoff involving his obligations on note held by another debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Sahu v. Union Carbide Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, concerted action liability cannot be used as a shortcut around veil piercing requirements to hold a parent liable for the actions of a subsidiary.
Document Preview: TORTS - Equitable Relief. Victims of pollution were not entitled to recovery on claims for medical monitoring and remediation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Hoffmann v. Dandurand
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Dallas.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether corporations operate as single business enterprise, as would permit application of single business enterprise theory to disregard separate existence of corporations when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, include, but are not limited to: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have special jurisdiction over nonresident chief executive officer of corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Citizens Bank of Texas, N.A.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Waco.
Headnote: Under single business enterprise theory, when two corporations are not operated as separate entities but instead integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, it may be equitable, under exceptional circumstances, to hold each constituent corporation liable for the debts and liabilities incurred in the common enterprise.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Commercial Paper. Collecting and payor banks' conduct did not cause damages to depositary bank from customer's check kiting scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Wortham v. Dow Chemical Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Under the single business enterprise theory, when two or more corporations are operated as integrated entities, using resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Successor Liability. Corporation was not the corporate successor to employer of worker who died from lung cancer due to asbestos exposure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Coleman v. Klockner & Co. AG
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether corporations operate as a single business enterprise include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) common employees; (2) common offices; (3) centralized accounting; (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees; (5) common business name; (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Jurisdiction could not be asserted over nonresident German companies, in action brought by veterans of Persian Gulf War.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: PHC-Minden, L.P. v. Kimberly-Clark Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether a single business enterprise is present, as would subject one corporation to personal jurisdiction based on activities of another corporation, include (1) common employees, (2) common offices, (3) centralized accounting, (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, (5) common business name, (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: HEALTH - Jurisdiction. Hospital operator's doing business in Texas would be imputed to medical center under single business enterprise theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: PHC-Minden, L.P. v. Kimberly-Clark Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Tyler.
Headnote: To recover against corporation under a finding of a "single business enterprise theory," no proof of fraud is required.

Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.

Title: National Plan Administrators, Inc. v. National Health Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Austin.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise doctrine," when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.

Title: Fluorine On Call, Ltd. v. Fluorogas Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas' "single business enterprise theory," when corporations are not operated as separate entities but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: Factors for determining whether corporations operated as a single business enterprise, as would support the disregard of corporate structure, include whether the corporations have common employees, common offices, centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, common business name, services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Bridgestone Corp. v. Lopez
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi–Edinburg.
Headnote: The "single business enterprise" theory, used to disregard corporate structure, is not synonymous with the doctrine of alter ego; although the alter ego theory and single business enterprise theory are both equitable doctrines, an important distinction is that the alter ego theory, unlike the single business enterprise theory, generally involves proof of fraud, that is, proof that the corporation is organized and operated as merely a tool or business conduit of another corporation.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Japanese tire manufacturer was not entitled to special appearance for suit alleging defect.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re Flutie New York Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider when evaluating whether a corporation has been so controlled or dominated as to permit a piercing of corporate veil include: (1) absence of corporate formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone number; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property which was used by other corporations as if were their own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil would be pierced to hold debtor's principal personally liable for debts of bankruptcy estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts consider several factors when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, including: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Likelihood of success on corporate veil-piercing claim supported propriety of attachment order.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Ass'n Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts will consider following factors when determining whether to pierce corporate veil under New York law: (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether related corporations deal with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by other corporation as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Russian metal seller properly stated veil-piercing claim against corporate purchasers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Western Oil & Gas JV, Inc. v. Castlerock Oil Co., Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under "single business enterprise theory," when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose; like the alter-ego doctrine, the single business enterprise doctrine is an equitable remedy which applies when the corporate form is used as part of an unfair device to achieve inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Sharing office equipment and space was not enough to be alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Seminal inquiry in determining applicability of alter ego doctrine in labor law context is whether two or more coexisting employers performing the same work are in fact one business, separated only in form, and in answering question, courts employ multifactor test to determine whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: IGEN Intern., Inc. v. Roche Diagnostics GmbH
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the act of one corporation is not regarded as the act of another merely because the first corporation is a subsidiary of the other, or because the two may be treated as part of a single economic enterprise for some other purpose; rather, to pierce the corporate veil based on an agency or "alter ego" theory, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Continuation of suit against licensor was not sham, so licensee was immune from tort liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: In re U-Haul Intern., Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, San Antonio.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise" doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Sanctions. Manufacturer and insurer were not on business enterprise, and thus discovery sanctions were not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: A court may disregard the separateness of affiliated corporations, and pierce the corporate veil, when the corporations are not operated as separate entities, but are manipulated or controlled as one enterprise through their interrelationship to cause illegality, fraud, or injustice, or to permit one economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The indicia of common identity, excessive fragmentation, or single-business-enterprise corporations may include, among other factors justifying piercing the corporate veil, the intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: El Puerto De Liverpool, S.A. De C.V. v. Servi Mundo Llantero S.A. De C.V.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether single business enterprise is present, as would subject corporation to personal jurisdiction based on activities of enterprise, include (1) common employees, (2) common offices, (3) centralized accounting, (4) payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, (5) common business name, (6) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, (7) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and (8) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mexican corporation with bank account and subsidiaries in Texas could be sued in Texas.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Heslop v. UCB, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Guidelines considered under Kansas law for determining alter ego status include: (1) whether parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers, (3) whether parent finances subsidiary, (4) whether parent subscribed to all of the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation, (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent, (8) whether in papers of parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as a department or division, (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent, and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are observed.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Pleading. Terminated employee failed to state claim for fraudulent misrepresentation against employers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Important distinction between alter ego doctrine, and single business enterprise doctrine, is that alter ego theory generally involves proof of fraud, i.e., proof that the corporation is organized and operated as merely a tool or business conduit of another corporation, while to recover under a finding of a single business enterprise, no proof of fraud is required, as theory instead relies on equity analogies to partnership principles of liability.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: No showing of fraud is required to pierce the corporate veil under single business enterprise theory, and, when two corporations are not operated as separate entities but instead integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, it may be equitable, under exceptional circumstances, to hold each constituent corporation liable for the debts and liabilities incurred in the common enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: North American Van Lines, Inc. v. Emmons
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Beaumont.
Headnote: Single enterprise doctrine is not a common-law tort to which the proportionate responsibility statute applies, but, rather, is an equitable doctrine which treats two interrelated corporations as one under partnership-type principles. V.T.C.A., Civil Practice & Remedies Code § 33.013(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Interstate carrier and its subsidiary were operated as a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Nichols v. Pabtex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: The "single business enterprise doctrine" applies when two or more business entities act as one; under the doctrine, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee, who already received worker's compensation benefits, was not precluded from recovering under FELA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Nichols v. Pabtex, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Texas, Beaumont Division.
Headnote: When determining whether corporations have been maintained as separate entities for the purpose of application of the single business enterprise doctrine, courts consider: common employees and offices, centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, common business names, services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Employee, who already received worker's compensation benefits, was not precluded from recovering under FELA.

Title: Smith v. McLeod Distributing, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Indicia of common "identity," "excessive fragmentation," or "single business enterprise" corporations, as required to pierce the corporate veil, may include, among other factors, intermingling of business transactions, functions, property, employees, funds, records, and corporate names in dealing with the public.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced to hold another corporation liable for commercial debt.

Title: Rio Grande Valley Gas Co. v. City of Edinburg
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Corpus Christi-Edinburg.
Headnote: Under the "single business enterprise" theory, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for the debts incurred by the other component entities in pursuit of that business purpose.

Title: Rio Grande Valley Gas Co. v. City of Edinburg

Headnote: Factors relevant to determining whether a "single business enterprise" is present include common employees, common offices, centralized accounting, payment of wages by one corporation to another corporation's employees, common business name, services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation, undocumented transfers of funds between corporations, and unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations.
Document Preview: ENERGY AND UTILITIES - Oil and Gas. Liability for franchisee's conduct extended throughout natural gas suppliers' corporate family.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1054 Single business enterprise >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: The following factors may be considered in determining whether a group of entities constitute a "single business enterprise" for purposes of imposing common liability, although factors are not exhaustive and no single factor is dispositive: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Title: In re Schimmelpenninck
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: A single business enterprise remedy defeats the corporate form, under Texas law, when two or more organizations that are separate de jure pool or integrate their resources de facto to achieve a common business purpose; if such commonality is established, each constituent organization may be held liable for the debts incurred by one or more of the others in pursuit of that common business purpose.

Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: For evidence of a common enterprise, pursuant to which each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, a court looks to common control; the sharing of office space and officers and employees; whether business is transacted through a maze of interrelated companies; the commingling of corporate funds and failure to maintain separation of companies; unified advertising; and evidence that reveals that no real distinction exists between the corporate defendants.

Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise doctrine, where each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, avoids situations where corporations are so entwined that a judgment absolving one of them of liability would provide the other defendants with a clear mechanism for avoiding the terms of an order.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Attorneys and mortgage assistance relief providers did not engage in unfair or deceptive practices violative of New Mexico Unfair Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: New Mexico ex rel. Balderas v. Real Estate Law Center, P.C.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: The common enterprise inquiry, where each entity in a group of interrelated companies can be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of other entities in that group, is not an alter ego analysis; the entities formally may be separate corporations but operate as a common enterprise.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. Attorneys and mortgage assistance relief providers did not engage in unfair or deceptive practices violative of New Mexico Unfair Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee stated plausible strong-arm claim to avoid transfer of right to acquire real estate.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, it is appropriate to depart from the general principle of corporate separateness in two situations: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of this intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of the activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Hebert v. Vantage Travel Service, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, disregard of corporate separateness is permitted when two factors are met: (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Class Actions. Class certification was warranted with respect to proposed class of passengers on malfunctioning tour boat.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Alliance Document Preparation
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Courts are permitted to consider a variety of factors when deciding whether a common enterprise exists; for instance, courts may consider whether companies are under common ownership and control, whether they pool resources and staff, whether they share telephone numbers, employees, and e-mail systems, and whether they jointly participated in a shared business venture or referred customers to one another.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Unfair Practices. FTC was likely to succeed on its claim that corporations and individuals engaged in the business of student loan debt relief violated the FTC Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Federal Trade Commission v. Vantage Point Services, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a common enterprise, or maze of interrelated companies, exists, as a basis for joint and several liability, a court considers the pattern and framework of the whole enterprise, and relevant factors include whether the corporate defendants (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Debt Collection. Fact issues as to whether owners of debt engaged in common enterprise with third-party call-initiators precluded summary judgment in favor of FTC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Medici v. Lifespan Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: There are two scenarios in which the corporate form may be disregarded under Massachusetts law: (1) the first is when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the inter-corporate relationship, and (2) the second is when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Discipline. Scientist had to exhaust his administrative remedies before Department of Health and Human Services' Office of Research Integrity before bringing suit challenging...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission v. Trade Exchange Network Limited
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In determining whether several business entities are operating as a common enterprise, courts look to whether the companies: (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing; and courts also look to whether corporate formalities are observed and whether the companies conduct business at arm's length.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Commodity Futures. Prediction-related contracts were binary options that were subject to regulation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a relationship between two corporations may result in joint liability when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. E.M.A. Nationwide, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Courts generally find that a common enterprise exists, so as to disregard corporate structure and impose liability upon subsidiaries, if, for example, businesses: (1) maintain officers and employees in common; (2) operate under common control; (3) share offices; (4) commingle funds; and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Protection. Marketers and sellers of debt-relief services were jointly and severally liable, under common enterprise theory, for violations of Federal Trade...

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: F.T.C. v. Tax Club, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a common enterprise exists among a set of corporate defendants, such that each defendant may be held jointly and severally liable for the actions of the other defendants, courts consider a set of non-dispositive factors, including whether they: (1) maintain officers and employees in common, (2) operate under common control, (3) share offices, (4) commingle funds, and (5) share advertising and marketing.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. FTC, Florida, and New Jersey stated claim for common enterprise liability among corporations for deceptive telemarketing tactics.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Bridge Street Automotive, Inc. v. Green Valley Oil, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate formalities may be disregarded and the corporate veil may be pierced (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Gas station owner did not establish relatedness prong of test for specific jurisdiction over lessor's alleged alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Admiral Ins. Co., Inc. v. Arrowood Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, when corporations are not operated as separate entities, but rather integrate their resources to achieve common business purpose, each constituent corporation may be held liable for debts incurred in pursuit of that business purpose.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Excess and Umbrella. Excess insurer had subrogation claim based on primary insurer's failure to tender its policy limits.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: TechTarget, Inc. v. Spark Design, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a court may disregard corporate formalities and pierce the corporate veil when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Advertising firm could not pierce the corporate veil of client.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Logistics Information Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of the corporate entities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. State law governed evidentiary issue in strong-arm avoidance proceeding.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Trabucco v. Intesa Sanpaolo, S.p.A.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, one corporation is considered to be mere alter ego when it has been so dominated by another corporation and its separate identity so disregarded, that it primarily transacted dominator's business rather than its own.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING - Jurisdiction. Bank purposefully availed itself of privilege of conducting activities within New York forum.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although common ownership of the stock of two or more corporations together with common management, standing alone, will not give rise to liability under Massachusetts law on the part of one corporation for the acts of another corporation or its employees, additional facts may be such as to permit the conclusion that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities, particularly (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Callahan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, there are two circumstances in which piercing corporate veil is appropriate: (1) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising form of pervasive control, in activities of another, and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship; or (2) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise, with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Tax lien did not attach to property titled solely in name of taxpayer's wife.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Friedlander Capital Management Corp.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida, West Palm Beach Division.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, "identity rule" requires that proponent of veil piercing claim show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, and adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Reverse veil piercing could be applied defensively to defeat fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To determine "alter ego" status in situation where new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old, court asks whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; no one of these factors is controlling but rather analysis is flexible, and court evaluates all relevant factors together and can find alter ego status even if not all of them are present.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Zimmerman v. Cambridge Credit Counseling Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Massachusetts law permits piercing of the corporate veil under the alter ego doctrine where there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Admissions. Defendants were not entitled to withdrawal of admissions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Milan v. Centennial Communications Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: To determine whether separate corporations constitute a single employer, courts consider the following factors, none of which is controlling or needs to be present: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) common management; (3) centralized control of labor relations; and (4) common ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employees who signed separation agreements knowingly and voluntarily waived all claims against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In a case where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors generally applied to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil are not exclusive, and the court may consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Brown v. ANA Ins. Group
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: When a group of associated business entities or corporations integrate their resources to achieve a common business purpose and do not abide by the formalities of law for operation as separate companies, a single business enterprise may be declared.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Insolvent Insurers. Insurance Commissioner breached fiduciary duty to insolvent insurer's owners by failing to supervise investment advisors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Ontos, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, a claim may be brought against the "alter ego" of a corporation when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting; in such circumstances, courts may allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil of limited liability in order to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Trustee had standing to settle claims brought by debtor's former officers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Davlyn Mfg. Co., Inc. v. H&M Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or corporation is an alter ego or successor of a corporation, the court should consider the nature of the corporate entities' ownership and control, including commonality of stockholders or officers, common use of employees, business locations, or sales systems, common marketing or trademarking; similarity of core business lines, and commingling of funds and assets; court should also consider the sufficiency of consideration paid for the transfer of the predecessor's assets or product line, as well as any other indicia of fraudulent intent in the creation of the second entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Massachusetts courts will pierce corporate veil only when there is compelling evidence of one of two situations: (1) that there is active and pervasive control of related business entities by same controlling persons, as well as a fraudulent or injurious consequence by reason of relationship among these business entities; or (2) there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or a serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the factors that may be considered when determining whether to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant corporation are: (1) identity of stock ownership, (2) common directors and officers, (3) unified administrative control, (4) directors and officers of one entity operate independently in interest of the other, (5) one corporation financing another, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) corporation causing incorporation of another, (8) one corporation paying salaries and expenses of another, (9) corporation receives no business except from other corporation, (10) corporation using property of the other as its own, (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities, (12) common employees, (13) common offices, (14) central accounting, (15) undocumented transfer of funds, (16) unclear allocation of profit and loss between the two corporate entities, and (17) excessive fragmentation of single business enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1055 Common enterprise >
Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veil may be pierced in order to impute liability among differing corporate entities: (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of that intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil could be pierced in order to permit creditor's proof of claim.

Title: United Paperworkers Intern. Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. Alden Corrugated Container Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, one corporation may be held liable for actions of another when there is act of indirect participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of inter-corporate relationship, or when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard for separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts consider the following factors to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed, (2) whether the capitalization is adequate, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arm's length, (8) whether the corporation is treated as independent profit center, (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.

Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.

Title: Mills v. Ethicon, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, in determining whether a subsidiary is acting as an agent of the parent, the court must consider four factors: (1) whether the subsidiary is doing business in the forum that would otherwise be performed by the parent, (2) whether there is common ownership of the parent and subsidiary, (3) whether there is financial dependency, and (4) whether the parent interferes with the subsidiary's personnel, disregards the corporate formalities, and/or controls the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.

Title: GBB Properties Two, LLC v. Stirling Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Third Circuit.
Headnote: Factors for determining applicability of single-business-entity exception to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) identity of ownership; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in interest of that corporation; (5) corporate financing; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) causing incorporation of affiliated corporation; (8) payment of salaries and expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by affiliated corporations; (10) use of property; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by employees; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise.

Title: Lieberman v. Corporacion Experienca Unica, S.A.

Title: United States v. Executive Health Resources, Inc.

Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority

Title: Norfolk Southern Ry. Co. v. National Union Fire Ins. of Pittsburgh, PA
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia.
Headnote: Under West Virginia law, the mere showing that one corporation is owned by another or that they share common officers is not a sufficient justification for a court to disregard their separate corporate structure, and mutuality of interest is not sufficient either, without the countermingling of funds or property interests, or prejudice to creditors; rather it must be shown that the corporation is so organized and controlled as to be a mere adjunct or instrumentality of the other.

Title: Pro Tanks Leasing v. Midwest Propane and Refined Fuels, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: The exercise of the control which stock ownership gives to the corporate parents will not create liability beyond the assets of the subsidiary, and that control includes the election of directors, the making of by-laws, and the doing of all other acts incident to the legal status of stockholders; nor will a duplication of some or all of the directors or executive officers be fatal in the determination of whether to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Tanfield Engineering Systems, Inc. v. Thornton
Court: Supreme Court of Mississippi.
Headnote: Even if the parent owns all of the subsidiary's stock and the two entities share common management, this does not operate as a merger of the two corporations into a single entity; corporate identity is not disregarded unless it is shown that one corporation is a mere instrumentality or agency or adjunct in that sense, or as a sham or is used in fraud, by the dominant corporation.

Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: When a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil on the alter ego theory, the court considers whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.

Title: In re Moll Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In deciding, for alter ego purposes, whether corporation and its stockholder(s) operated as single economic unit, Delaware courts consider any: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) insolvency of corporation at time; (5) siphoning of corporate funds; (6) absence of corporate records; and (7) fact that corporation is merely facade for the operations of its dominant stockholder or stockholders.

Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, the fact that one person controls two corporations is not sufficient to make the two corporations and the controlling stockholder the same person under the law.

Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: The alter ego test encompasses a host of factors, including: (1) commingling of funds and other assets, failure to segregate funds of the separate entities, and the unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, (2) the treatment by an individual of the assets of the corporation as his own, (3) the failure to obtain authority to issue stock or to subscribe to or issue the same, (4) the holding out by an individual that he is personally liable for the debts of the corporation, the failure to maintain minutes or adequate corporate records, and the confusion of the records of the separate entities, (5) the identical equitable ownership in the two entities, the identification of the equitable owners thereof with the domination and control of the two entities, identification of the directors and officers of the two entities in the responsible supervision and management, sole ownership of all of the stock in a corporation by one individual or the members of a family, (6) the use of the same office or business location, the employment of the same employees and/or attorney, (7) the failure to adequately capitalize a corporation, the total absence of corporate assets, and undercapitalization, (8) the use of a corporation as a mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for a single venture or the business of an individual or another corporation, (9) the concealment and misrepresentation of the identity of the responsible ownership, management and financial interest, or concealment of personal business activities, (10) the disregard of legal formalities and the failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, (11) the use of the corporate entity to procure labor, services or merchandise for another person or entity, (12) the diversion of assets from a corporation by or to a stockholder or other person or entity, to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate the assets in one and the liabilities in another, (13) the contracting with another with intent to avoid performance by use of a corporate entity as a shield against personal liability, or the use of a corporation as a subterfuge of illegal transactions, and (14) and the formation and use of a corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity.

Title: Atateks Foreign Trade, Ltd. v. Private Label Sourcing, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: One corporation dominated and controlled other corporation, and thus corporate veil of dominating corporation could be pierced to hold it liable under New York law for debts of dominated corporation, where those corporations did not adhere to corporate formalities, they had overlapping owners, officers, directors, and personnel, they did not deal with each other at arm's length and were not independent profit centers, dominated corporation had inadequate capitalization based on its conceded insolvency, and they shared office space and equipment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Alter ego could be jointly and severally liable for all damages.

Title: Vanderbilt Mortg. and Finance, Inc. v. Flores
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Corpus Christi Division.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation has complete control over subsidiary, for purposes of applying alter ego doctrine under Texas law, courts examine whether: (1) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (2) parent finances subsidiary; (3) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (4) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (5) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (6) daily operations of the corporations are not kept separate; (7) directors of subsidiary act in primary and independent interest of parent; and (8) alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms' length.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Liens. Manufactured home purchasers had standing to sue under Texas fraudulent lien statute.
