Title: Larco, Inc. v. Strebeck
Court: Court of Appeals of Arkansas.
Headnote: All corporations, regardless of the fact that the holders of stock and the officers of the corporation are identical, are separate and distinct legal entities, and thus, it follows that, in the absence of facts on which liability can be predicated, one such corporation is not liable for the debts of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Court clearly erred in finding that corporations were jointly and severally liable for commissions owed to employee.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Koninklijke Philips Electronics N.V. v. The ADS Group
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: On a claim to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, when analyzing the domination and control element, a court considers: (1) whether corporate formalities are observed; (2) whether the capitalization is adequate; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) whether the corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporation is treated as an independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of the dominated corporation; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were the dominator's own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Computers and Electronics. Controlling corporation to produce products that infringed patent was not inducement.

Title: Schreiber v. Philips Display Components Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Essential inquiry under an alter ego analysis is whether there was a bona fide discontinuance and a true change of ownership or merely a disguised continuance of the old employer.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Employer's successor was not alter ego of employer and thus did not retain employer's labor law obligations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, the eighteen factors a court must look at in determining whether to apply single business enterprise (SBE) theory to fuse either affiliated or unaffiliated corporations for jurisdictional purposes include: whether one corporation has sufficient ownership interest in another to give it actual working control, whether common directors or officers exist, whether a unified administrative control apparatus is present, whether the business functions of the companies are similar or supplementary, whether the directors of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation or instead in the interest of another corporation, whether one corporation finances or pays the salaries and expenses of another corporation, whether one corporation is inadequately capitalized or receives no business other than that given to it by another corporation, whether a corporation uses the property of another corporation as its own, complies with corporate formalities, or keeps common employees or offices with another corporation, and whether financial transactions suggest that two companies that are separate in form are in fact a single enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Companies were single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law for jurisdictional purposes.

Title: Bona Fide Demolition and Recovery, LLC v. Crosby Const. Co. of Louisiana, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Common ownership is not dispositive in determining whether related companies constitute a single business enterprise (SBE) under Louisiana law even when the common ownership amounts to complete ownership, such as when two affiliated companies are wholly owned subsidiaries of a single parent corporation.

Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Mississippi.
Headnote: General rule of law in Mississippi is that two or more corporations maintain their distinct legal identities even though the same individual may own stock in the several corporations and even though such corporations may have the same person as officers.

Title: Spagnola v. Chubb Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Allegations suggesting some overlap between operations of parent corporation and its subsidiaries, including claims that parent and subsidiaries were considered as a whole in credit agreement and substantial overlap of officers and directors, were not, without more, sufficient to impose alter ego liability on the parent under Minnesota or Indiana law for subsidiary's alleged breach of contract.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Class Actions. Insureds could not fairly or adequately represent putative class, barring class certification in breach of contract action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Brookridge Funding Corp. v. Aquamarine, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Although common ownership of the stock of two or more corporations together with common management, standing alone, will not give rise to liability under Massachusetts law on the part of one corporation for the acts of another corporation or its employees, additional facts may be such as to permit the conclusion that an agency or similar relationship exists between the entities, particularly (1) when there is active and direct participation by the representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in the activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of the intercorporate relationship, or (2) when there is a confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of the separate nature of the corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about the manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Fish buyer was not unjustly enriched at secured lender's expense.

Title: In re BH S & B Holdings LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, wholly-owned subsidiaries may share officers, directors, and employees with their parent, without requiring the court to infer, for purposes of veil-piercing, that the subsidiary is a mere instrumentality for the parent and without requiring the court to conclude that those officers and directors were not functioning properly.

Title: Fantazia Intern. Corp. v. CPL Furs New York, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce corporate veil include: the disregard of corporate formalities, inadequate capitalization, intermingling of funds, overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, common office space or telephone numbers, the degree of discretion demonstrated by the allegedly dominated corporation, whether dealings between the entities are at arm's length, whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, and the payment or guaranty of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity; but no one factor is dispositive.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. New York furrier was not alter ego of German corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: McAnaney v. Astoria Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York., E.D. New York.
Headnote: Courts look to several non-exclusive factors to determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, including: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) common office space, addresses and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group; and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were their own.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - States. Mortgagors' claim against mortgagees under New York Real Property Law was preempted by Home Owners' Loan Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Saba Enterprises, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, although no one factor is dispositive, ten factors may be considered in determining the sufficiency of parent domination over the subsidiary for purposes of piercing the corporate veil: (1) absence of corporate formalities and paraphernalia, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) movement of funds for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space and contact information, (6) limited amount of business discretion exercised by the subsidiary, (7) lack of arms' length dealings between the parent and the subsidiary, (8) failure to treat relevant entities as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the subsidiary's debts by the parent, and (10) use by the parent of the subsidiary's property as if the property were owned by the parent.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Chapter 7 trustee satisfied fraud pleading rule in asserting actual fraudulent transfer claims.

Title: In re SMTC Mfg. of Texas
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Texas, Austin Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, proof of identity of shareholders or of corporate directors and officers or of domination by parent of its subsidiary's affairs will not alone justify treatment of the two as one business unit, nor will parent's ownership of 100% of subsidiary's stock.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Even obligation on absolute and unconditional guarantee may be discounted for fraudulent transfer avoidance purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Board of Managers of 195 Hudson Street Condominium v. Jeffrey M. Brown Associates, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In order to determine whether corporation is dominated, for purposes of piercing corporate veil under New York law, courts consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether alleged dominator deals with corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) intermingling of property between alleged dominator and corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Condominium association board's claim against holding company was precluded by res judicata.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re South African Apartheid Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: INTERNATIONAL LAW - Pleading. Allegations were sufficient to sustain claims for aiding and abetting apartheid against automotive manufacturers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re The Heritage Organization, L.L.C.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when two entities with common ownership fail to follow legal formalities when contracting with each other, this is tantamount to declaring that they are indeed one in the same, for veil-piercing purposes.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. LLC's membership distributions were actually fraudulent to creditors under Texas law.

Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant to determining whether a corporation's form should be respected include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: Classic Maritime Inc. v. Limbungan Makmur SDN BHD
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether a company is the alter ego of another, as would warrant piercing of corporate veil, a court considers the following factors, among others: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm"s length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Vessel owner asserted valid maritime claim against guarantor of charter contracts, supporting attachment of $20,457,047.72.

Title: Arctic Ocean Intern., Ltd. v. High Seas Shipping Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When considering whether to pierce a corporate veil based on allegations of alter ego liability, courts may consider the following factors: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Eleven months of failed attempts at locating funds subject to Rule B maritime attachment rendered court without jurisdiction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gateway I Group, Inc. v. Park Ave. Physicians, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Indicia of a situation warranting veil-piercing include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Landlord's allegations were sufficient to state claim that medical groups assumed assignment of lease.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Troyk v. Farmers Group, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Factors for the trial court to consider in applying alter ego doctrine include the commingling of funds and assets of the two entities, identical equitable ownership in the two entities, use of the same offices and employees, disregard of corporate formalities, identical directors and officers, and use of one as a mere shell or conduit for the affairs of the other; no one characteristic governs, but the courts must look at all the circumstances to determine whether the doctrine should be applied.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Premiums. Premium in statute requiring insurance policy to state the premium, includes service charge imposed for payment of stated insurance premium for term...

Title: Guinan v. A.I. duPont Hosp. for Children
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Factors to consider when determining whether complete domination exists, for purposes of determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) intermingling of funds, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Warranties. Minor child who received heart stent did not have breach of implied warranty claim against stent manufacturer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Telenor Mobile Communications AS v. Storm LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, court should consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Contempt. Sanction of $100,000 per day, doubling every 30 days until shareholder complied with arbitration award, was appropriate.

Title: SSP Partners v. Gladstrong Investments (USA) Corp.
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Corporations are not liable for each other's obligations merely because of centralized control, mutual purposes, and shared finances; there must also be evidence of abuse, or injustice and inequity, meaning not a subjective perception of unfairness by an individual judge or juror, but rather, fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporations can not be held liable for each other's obligations merely because they are part of a single business enterprise.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Amaranth Natural Gas Commodities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that are relevant under New York law to determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of fluids; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.

Title: Ketchem v. American Acceptance, Co., LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Indiana, Hammond Division.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, while no one talismanic fact will justify with impunity piercing the corporate veil, a careful review of the entire relationship between various corporate entities, their directors, and officers, may reveal that such an equitable action is warranted.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debtor stated claim under FDCPA for improperly seeking attorney fees for representation by related entity.

Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, the separate corporate entities of two corporations may not be disregarded merely because one owns the stock of another; the principle that a corporation is a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders, directors, and officers applies even where one corporation wholly owns another and the two have mutual dealings.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Judson Atkinson Candies, Inc. v. Latini-Hohberger Dhimantec
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, while having common officers and directors is generally a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil, this factor is insufficient to justify disregarding the corporate form because it is a common business practice that exists in most parent and subsidiary relationships.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment creditor failed to demonstrate that debtor was alter ego of parent company, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Michigan Elec. Employees Pension Fund v. Encompass Elec. & Data, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: To determine "alter ego" status in situation where new employer is merely disguised continuance of the old, court asks whether the two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision, and ownership; no one of these factors is controlling but rather analysis is flexible, and court evaluates all relevant factors together and can find alter ego status even if not all of them are present.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Collective Bargaining. Electrical contractor whose president signed letters of assent was bound by CBAs expressly incorporated by reference therein.

Title: Dewey v. Volkswagen AG
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: To determine if a subsidiary is acting as an agent of the parent under New Jersey law, courts consider (1) whether the subsidiary is doing business in the forum that would otherwise be performed by the parent, (2) whether there is common ownership of the parent and subsidiary, (3) whether there is financial dependency, and (4) whether the parent interferes with the subsidiary's personnel, disregards the corporate formalities, and or controls the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. United States subsidiary was an agent by law of manufacturer for purpose of service of process.

Title: K.C. Properties of N.W. Arkansas, Inc. v. Lowell Inv. Partners, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Arkansas.
Headnote: All corporations, regardless of the fact that the holders of stock and the officers of the corporation are identical, are separate and distinct legal entities; and it follows that, in the absence of facts on which liability can be predicated, one such corporation is not liable for the debts of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Statute did not allow minority LLC member to bring breach of fiduciary duty claim against members of management LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In determining whether one corporation exercised control over another to the extent necessary to pierce the corporate veil, under Missouri law, courts look to the ownership and creation of both corporations, the management of the corporations, the physical location of corporate offices, and the transfer of assets, contracts, and employees between the corporations.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Title: Greater St. Louis Const. Laborers Welfare Fund v. Mertens Plumbing and Mechanical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Missouri, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, connected ownership via spouses satisfies the factor of common ownership for purposes of piercing corporate veil and holding a defendant corporation liable for the torts of another corporation.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. LLC and corporation were alter egos of judgment debtor.

Title: HOK Sport, Inc. v. FC Des Moines, L.C.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit.
Headnote: Mere identity of ownership and corporate management is not alone sufficient to permit a piercing of the corporate veil under Iowa law.

Title: In re Parmalat Securities Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, directors and officers holding positions with a parent and its subsidiary can "change hats" to represent the two corporations separately, despite their common ownership; courts generally presume that the directors are wearing their "subsidiary hats" and not their "parent hats" when acting for the subsidiary.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Auditor was not liable for looting of subsidiary's assets by parent's corrupt insiders.

Title: Milan v. Centennial Communications Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Puerto Rico.
Headnote: To determine whether separate corporations constitute a single employer, courts consider the following factors, none of which is controlling or needs to be present: (1) interrelation of operations; (2) common management; (3) centralized control of labor relations; and (4) common ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Contracts. Employees who signed separation agreements knowingly and voluntarily waived all claims against employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Four Seasons Mfg., Inc. v. 1001 Coliseum, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In a case where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, the eight factors generally applied to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil are not exclusive, and the court may consider additional factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used; (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees; (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar; and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of LLC was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mecco, Inc. v. Capital Hardware Supply, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, when determining whether two distinct corporate entities will be treated as one in the same, factors to be considered include: (1) the presence in both corporations of the same officers or directors; (2) common shareholders; (3) financial support of the subsidiary's operations by the parent; (4) underwriting the incorporation and purchase of all of the capital stock of the subsidiary by the parent corporation; (5) the fact that the subsidiary was organized with a grossly inadequate capital structure; (6) a joint accounting and payroll system; (7) the subsidiary lacks any substantial business contacts save the parent and operates solely with assets conveyed by the parent corporation; (8) in the financial statements of the parent, the subsidiary is referred to as a division of the parent corporation or obligations are assumed to be those of the parent; (9) the property of the subsidiary is used by the parent corporation as its own; (10) the individuals who exercise operating control over the subsidiary exercise it in the interest of the parent; and (11) failure to observe formal requirements in the operation of the subsidiary.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Liens. Companies were a single entity, for purposes of determining priority of federal tax liens.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's, London, Subscribing to Policy Number 501/NB03ACMD v. Nance
Court: United States District Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, factors in determining whether entity is instrument of or under domination of another entity, as required to pierce corporate veil, are: (1) parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) in papers of parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such, or as department or division; (9) directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary, but take direction from parent; (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Liability. Alter ego doctrine could not be used against innocent third-party insurer.

Title: Mouawad Nat. Co. v. Lazare Kaplan Intern. Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under the veil-piercing analysis, when considering whether a parent corporation exercised complete domination over its subsidiary under New York law, courts consider such factors as: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Manufacturer was not principal of seller of pink diamond.

Title: Corrigan v. U.S. Steel Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, proof of some overlapping management between subsidiary and parent is an insufficient basis to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Steel industry employees could not pierce corporate veil on claims for age discrimination and increased retirement benefits.

Title: In re Doctors Hosp. of Hyde Park, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, use of common officers and directors of itself does not render one corporation liable for obligations of another.

Title: In re Alstom SA
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in the determination of control or domination sufficient to pierce the veil under New York law include, among other things: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence; (2) inadequate capitalization; * * * (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; and (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length.

Title: Sofi Classic S.A. de C.V. v. Hurowitz
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, piercing corporate veil may be appropriate where: (1) there is active and pervasive control of related business entities by same controlling persons and there is fraudulent or injurious consequence by reason of relationship among those business entities, or (2) there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Mexican garment manufacturer stated claim for piercing corporate veil against officers of import company.

Title: LM Ins. Corp. v. SourceOne Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: In order to establish alter ego claim under Illinois law, evidence of control and instrumentality is usually shown by analyzing several factors including that entities shared officers or employees, did not maintain separate corporate records or comply with corporate formalities, that one entity was kept undercapitalized at expense of another, or that corporate funds were commingled.
Document Preview: TORTS - Conversion. Insurer failed to establish conversion claim against insured.

Title: Colindres v. QuitFlex Mfg.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Existence of common management and ownership and normal incidents of a parent-subsidiary relationship, such as parent's right to select directors and to set general policies, do not justify treating parent and its subsidiary as a single employer.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Class Actions. Proposed class would not be certified in employment discrimination litigation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Beck v. Consolidated Rail Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, to establish a parent corporation's domination over a subsidiary, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil of a parent corporation, courts may consider: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address, and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) the degree of discretion shown by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the dealings between the entities are at arms length; (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of the corporation's debts by the dominating entity, or individual; and (10) intermingling of property between the entities.
Document Preview: TORTS - Premises Liability. Former owner of property owed no direct duty to pedestrian injured when curb broke under her foot.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pfizer Inc. v. Synthon Holding, B.V.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, affiliated corporations in which the controlling interest in both is owned by the same person are considered "alter egos" if one affiliated corporation is dominated by another to the extent that the dominated corporation has no separate mind, will, or identity of its own.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Jurisdiction. Due process permitted exercise of jurisdiction over nonresident filer of abbreviated new drug application in infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Pfizer Inc. v. Synthon Holding, B.V.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. North Carolina.
Headnote: Under North Carolina law, instrumentality rule governing disregard of corporate form of corporation operating as mere instrumentality of affiliate applies when there is evidence of common ownership and actual working control, taken together with other factors suggesting domination of finances, policy, or business practice, such as undercapitalization, disregard of corporate formalities, and insolvency, but it is not the presence or absence of any particular factor that is determinative; rather, court looks to combination of factors which, when taken together with element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege, suggest that corporate entity attacked had no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, and was therefore the mere instrumentality or tool of dominant corporation.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Jurisdiction. Due process permitted exercise of jurisdiction over nonresident filer of abbreviated new drug application in infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: JSC Foreign Economic Association Technostroyexport v. International Development and Trade Services, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether requirement for piercing of corporate veil, under New York law, that owners exercise complete dominion over corporation with respect to transaction attacked, courts are to consider (1) absence of formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of corporate existence, such as issuance of stock, election of directors, and keeping of corporate records, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) payment or guarantee of debts of dominated corporation by other corporations in group, and (10) whether dominated corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate veil would be pierced in breach of contract case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Davlyn Mfg. Co., Inc. v. H&M Auto Parts, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In determining whether an individual or corporation is an alter ego or successor of a corporation, the court should consider the nature of the corporate entities' ownership and control, including commonality of stockholders or officers, common use of employees, business locations, or sales systems, common marketing or trademarking; similarity of core business lines, and commingling of funds and assets; court should also consider the sufficiency of consideration paid for the transfer of the predecessor's assets or product line, as well as any other indicia of fraudulent intent in the creation of the second entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Court lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants in patent infringement action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Trans-Tec Asia v. M/V HARMONY CONTAINER
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under federal common law, common ownership alone is insufficient to support disregard of corporate form.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Liens. Choice of law provision incorporated by bunker confirmation was material alteration of bunker contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: I & JC Corp. v. Helen of Troy L.P.
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, El Paso.
Headnote: Courts will not because of stock ownership or interlocking directorship disregard the separate legal identities of corporations, unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of the anti-trust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Jurisdiction. Defendant companies were alter egos of the other, thereby imputing tortious conduct to the other for jurisdictional purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Simeone ex rel. Estate Of Albert Francis Simeone, Jr. v. Bombardier-Rotax GmbH
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: In assessing whether subsidiary is alter ego of its parent, court should consider: (1) ownership of all or most of stock of subsidiary; (2) common officers and directors; (3) common marketing image; (4) common use of trademark or logo; (5) common use of employees; (6) integrated sales system; (7) interchange of managerial and supervisory personnel; (8) performance of business functions by subsidiary that principal corporation would normally conduct through its own agents or departments; (9) marketing by subsidiary on behalf of principal corporation, or as principal's exclusive distributor; and (10) receipt by officers of subsidiary corporation of instruction from principal corporation.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY - Jurisdiction. Austrian aircraft engine manufacturer was subject to personal jurisdiction under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Rondout Valley Central School Dist. v. Coneco Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, mere fact that corporate parent and subsidiary have overlapping officers or directors is not sufficient basis to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: EDUCATION - Property and Contracts. Contractor's actual performance was admission of obligation to perform.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: DeGraziano v. Verizon Communications, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether parent company has exercised complete domination over its subsidiary, as required to pierce corporate veil under New York law, court considers: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) adequacy of capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arms length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity, and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Consumer Credit. Wireless service provider did not waive right to arbitration.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Perfect 10, Inc. v. CCBill, LLC
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Elements of alter ego theory of liability are that (1) there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of two entities no longer exist and (2) failure to disregard their separate identities would result in fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: COPYRIGHTS - Internet. ISP came within DMCA safe harbor for providers who merely link users to infringing websites.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Holly & Smith Architects, Inc. v. St. Helena Congregate Facility
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Some of the factors that may be considered when determining whether to pierce corporate veil to reach dominant corporation are: (1) identity of stock ownership, (2) common directors and officers, (3) unified administrative control, (4) directors and officers of one entity operate independently in interest of the other, (5) one corporation financing another, (6) inadequate capitalization, (7) corporation causing incorporation of another, (8) one corporation paying salaries and expenses of another, (9) corporation receives no business except from other corporation, (10) corporation using property of the other as its own, (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities, (12) common employees, (13) common offices, (14) central accounting, (15) undocumented transfer of funds, (16) unclear allocation of profit and loss between the two corporate entities, and (17) excessive fragmentation of single business enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Client was corporation's alter ego, and thus corporation was liable for arbitration award.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: South Alabama Pigs, LLC v. Farmer Feeders, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Alabama, Northern Division.
Headnote: Under Alabama law, Iowa corporation owned by the same person that owned another Iowa corporation was not the alter ego of the other corporation, absent evidence that the two corporations were operated interchangeably.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause did not amount to agreement not to arbitrate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Roofers Local 149 Security Trust Fund v. Duane Smelser Roofing Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Seminal inquiry in determining applicability of alter ego doctrine in labor law context is whether two or more coexisting employers performing the same work are in fact one business, separated only in form, and in answering question, courts employ multifactor test to determine whether two enterprises have substantially identical management, business, purpose, operation, equipment, customers, supervision and ownership.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on multiemployer benefit funds' contribution claim under ERISA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bridas S.A.P.I.C. v. Government of Turkmenistan
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: To determine whether parent corporation may be bound by agreement entered into by its subsidiary, factors to consider include whether: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operated with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; (12) subsidiary does not observe corporate formalities; (13) directors of the subsidiary act in the primary and independent interest of the parent; (14) others pay or guarantee debts of the subsidiary; and (15) alleged parent deals with the subsidiary corporation at arms length.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Non-signatory Turkmenistan government could not be compelled to arbitrate a contract claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: River Colony Estates General Partnership v. Bayview Financial Trading Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: California courts recognize a public policy disfavoring the treatment of companies owned by the same individuals as a single or unitary enterprise unless these individuals assert their corporate separateness in order to commit frauds and misdeeds with impunity.
Document Preview: TORTS - Limitations. Statute of limitations was not tolled for brokers' alleged fraudulent concealment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: IGEN Intern., Inc. v. Roche Diagnostics GmbH
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, mere control and even total ownership of one corporation by another is not sufficient to warrant the disregard of a separate corporate entity, and a common central management alone is not a proper basis for disregarding separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Unfair Practices. Continuation of suit against licensor was not sham, so licensee was immune from tort liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Mid America Title Co. v. Transnation Title Ins. Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Arizona law, mere common ownership of corporations is insufficient to permit piercing of corporate veil based on alter ego relationship; showing is required that corporations share unity of control and that observance of corporate form would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Common ownership and consolidation of operations was insufficient to allow veil piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Cuiksa v. Hallmark Hall of Fame Productions, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: In determining whether subsidiary was "alter ego" of parent, under Kansas law, courts consider: (1) whether parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary, (2) whether corporations have common directors or officers, (3) whether parent finances subsidiary, (4) whether parent subscribed to all of capital stock of subsidiary or other wise causes its incorporation, (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital, (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary, (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent, (8) whether in papers of the parent, and in statements of its officers, subsidiary is referred to as such or as department or division, (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take direction from parent, and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed; no single factor is conclusive.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Fact questions precluded summary judgment in injured worker's negligence action against film company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Orenbuch v. North Shore Health Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: To determine whether the necessary dominion and control exists for the court to pierce the corporate veil under New York law, the court must examine several factors, including (1) the sharing of a common office, staff, and ownership; (2) the intermingling of funds; (3) the treatment of the corporations as one, not separate, profit centers; (4) the lack of the conventions of corporate existence; and (5) any inadequate earnings.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Debt collector's nondisclosure of relationship with affiliated organizations did not violate FDCPA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. Fidelity and Guar. Co. v. Braspetro Oil Services Co.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors that tend to show domination, for purposes of New York rule for "piercing the corporate veil," include: (1) the absence of the formalities and paraphernalia that are part and parcel of the corporate existence, i.e., issuance of stock, election of directors, keeping of corporate records and the like, (2) inadequate capitalization, (3) whether funds are put in and taken out of the corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes, (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel, (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities, (6) the amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation, (7) whether the related corporations deal with the dominated corporation at arms length, (8) whether the corporations are treated as independent profit centers, (9) the payment or guarantee of debts of the dominated corporation by other corporations in the group, and (10) whether the corporation in question had property that was used by other of the corporations as if it were its own.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Bonds. Sureties' obligations under performance bonds arose after owner fulfilled conditions precedent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: BMC Software Belgium, N.V. v. Marchand
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Courts will not because of stock ownership or interlocking directorship disregard the separate legal identities of corporations, unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of the anti-trust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Trial court did not have jurisdiction over foreign subsidiary of Houston based corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Oliver v. Pinnacle Homes, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Where a plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil in order to hold one corporation liable for another closely related corporation's debt, a court may consider various factors, including whether: (1) similar corporate names were used, (2) the corporations shared common principal corporate officers, directors, and employees, (3) the business purposes of the corporations were similar, and (4) the corporations were located in the same offices and used the same telephone numbers and business cards.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Manufacturer of modular home was not alter ego of builder for purposes of debt liability.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Wady v. Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. of America
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Factors to be considered in applying alter ego doctrine include: commingling of funds and other assets of two entities, holding out by one entity that it is liable for debts of other, identical equitable ownership in two entities, use of same offices and employees, and use of one as mere shell or conduit for affairs of other.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Bad Faith and Unfair Practices. Parent holding company could not be held liable for insurer's actions under alter ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Bagel Bros. Maple, Inc. v. Ohio Farmers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will pierce corporate veil, and thereby hold two corporations to constitute a single legal unit, only where one is so related to, or organized, or controlled by, the other as to be its instrumentality or alter ego; mere fact that both corporations have identical controlling shareholders, officers and directors does not, by itself, suffice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Veil Piercing. Debtor-corporation could not be held liable for related corporate entities' debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: U.S. ex rel. Wilkins v. North American Const. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Texas, Houston Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, twelve factors to be assessed when determining whether a subsidiary is the alter ego of its parent are: (1) parent and subsidiary have common stock ownership; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent and subsidiary have common business departments; (4) parent and subsidiary file consolidated financial statements and tax returns; (5) parent finances subsidiary; (6) parent caused incorporation of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary operates with grossly inadequate capital; (8) parent pays salaries and other expenses of subsidiary; (9) subsidiary receives no business except that given by parent; (10) parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; (11) daily operations of the two corporations are not kept separate; and (12) subsidiary does not observe basic corporate formalities, such as keeping separate books and records and holding shareholder and board meetings.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - False Claims. Allegations of hidden costs did not meet requirements of False Claims Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: MAG Portfolio Consult, GMBH v. Merlin Biomed Group LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.
Headnote: Under New York law, factors in whether veil-piercing is appropriate include: (1) disregard of corporate formalities; (2) inadequate capitalization; (3) intermingling of funds; (4) overlap in ownership, officers, directors, and personnel; (5) common office space, address and telephone numbers of corporate entities; (6) degree of discretion shown by allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether dealings between entities are at arm's length; (8) whether corporations are treated as independent profit centers; (9) payment or guarantee of corporation's debts by dominating entity; and (10) intermingling of property between entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Successor companies could not be compelled to arbitrate under agreement they were not party to.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Government of Virgin Islands, Bureau of Internal Revenue v. Lansdale
Court: District Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Croix.
Headnote: Some factors relevant to piercing the corporate veil under California law include commingling funds and other assets, unauthorized diversion of corporate funds or assets to other than corporate uses, treatment by individual of corporation's assets as his own, holding out by individual that he is personally liable for corporation's debts, identical equitable ownership in two entities, identification of equitable owners, directors and officers thereof with domination and control of two entities, sole ownership of all of stock in corporation by one individual or members of family, failure to adequately capitalize corporation, total absence of corporate assets and undercapitalization, use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality or conduit for single venture or business of individual, disregard of legal formalities and failure to maintain arm's length relationships among related entities, diversion of assets from corporation by or to stockholder or other person or entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities between entities so as to concentrate assets in one and liabilities in another, or use of corporation as subterfuge of illegal transactions, and formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Corporations' acts and omissions could be attributed to owners to satisfy Virgin Islands' long-arm statute.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Gammill v. Lincoln Life and Annuity Distributors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Mississippi, Jackson Division.
Headnote: Factors in whether corporate veil may be pierced under Mississippi law include whether: (1) parent owns all or majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) parent finances subsidiary; (4) parent subscribes to all capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent corporation or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers "subsidiary" is referred to as such or as department or division; (9) subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in subsidiary's interest but take direction from parent; and (10) formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are not observed.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Mere fact of parent-subsidiary relationship was insufficient to establish alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Grayson v. R.B. Ammon and Associates, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: The following factors may be considered in determining whether a group of entities constitute a "single business enterprise" for purposes of imposing common liability, although factors are not exhaustive and no single factor is dispositive: (1) corporations with identity or substantial identity of ownership, that is, ownership of sufficient stock to give actual working control; (2) common directors or officers; (3) unified administrative control of corporations whose business functions are similar or supplementary; (4) directors and officers of one corporation act independently in the interest of that corporation; (5) corporation financing another corporation; (6) inadequate capitalization; (7) corporation causing the incorporation of another affiliated corporation; (8) corporation paying the salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; (9) receiving no business other than that given to it by its affiliated corporations; (10) corporation using the property of another corporation as its own; (11) noncompliance with corporate formalities; (12) common employees; (13) services rendered by the employees of one corporation on behalf of another corporation; (14) common offices; (15) centralized accounting; (16) undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; (17) unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and (18) excessive fragmentation of a single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Related temporary staffing companies could be deemed single business enterprise for liability purposes.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Factors that New York courts consider in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil are as follows: (1) whether corporate formalities were observed; (2) whether capitalization was adequate; (3) whether funds were put in and taken out of corporation for personal rather than corporate purposes; (4) whether there is overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel; (5) whether corporate entities share common office space, address and telephone numbers; (6) amount of business discretion displayed by the allegedly dominated corporation; (7) whether the alleged dominator deals with dominated corporation at arms length; (8) whether corporation is treated as independent profit center; (9) whether others pay or guarantee debts of dominated corporation; and (10) whether corporation in question had property that was used by the alleged dominator as if it were his/her own.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: In re Computer Engineering Associates, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, incidents of common ownership and management, standing alone, are not enough to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Joint deposit arrangement was not absolute transfer of debtor-contractor's interest in payments.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Medina v. Four Winds Intern. Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Wyoming.
Headnote: Under Wyoming law, parent corporation and subsidiary's unity of ownership and interlocking directorates, standing alone, are not sufficient basis upon which to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parties injured in traffic accident could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1050 Separate Corporations;  Disregarding Separate Entities > 101k1056 Identity of directors, officers, or shareholders >
Title: Retzler v. Pratt and Whitney Co.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fifth Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, sole ownership of stock and common directors and officers between parent and subsidiary are only some of the factors to be considered in determining whether or not the corporate fiction should be disregarded and the shareholders held liable.

Title: Land Ocean Logistics, Inc. v. Aqua Gulf Corp.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: In determining whether a subsidiary was a mere instrumentality of the parent corporation, as will allow corporate veil to be pierced under New Jersey law, courts apply the traditional common law factors, including the presence in both corporations of the same officers, directors, and shareholders, financial support of the subsidiary's operations by the parent, whether the property of the subsidiary is used by the parent corporation as its own, the failure of a subsidiary to observe the formal requirements attributable to its operation, and the involvement of the parent's corporate officers in the day-to-day business of the subsidiary.

Title: ESI, Inc. v. Coastal Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Factors to aid in determining whether, under New York law, subsidiary is the "mere department" of parent, as would allow corporate veil to be pierced, for jurisdictional purposes are: (1) common ownership, (2) financial dependency of the subsidiary on the parent, (3) the degree to which the parent interferes in the selection of the subsidiary's executive personnel and fails to observe corporate formality, and (4) the degree of the parent's control over the subsidiary's marketing and operational policies; first factor, common ownership, is essential to the assertion of jurisdiction over a foreign related corporation, while the other three factors are "important."

Title: Gardemal v. Westin Hotel Co.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, degree of control necessary for finding parent corporation is alter ego of subsidiary is not mere majority or complete stock control but such domination of finances, policies and practices that the controlled corporation has, so to speak, no separate mind, will, or existence of its own and is but a business conduit for its principal; thus, one-hundred percent ownership and identity of directors and officers are, even together, an insufficient basis for applying the alter ego theory to pierce the corporate veil

Title: Doe v. Gelineau
Court: Supreme Court of Rhode Island.
Headnote: The mere fact that a person holds an office in two corporations that may be dealing with each other and that have offices in the same building, without more, is not enough to make them identical in contemplation of law.
