Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust

Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, incidents of common ownership and management, standing alone, are not sufficient to permit a piercing of corporate veil.

Title: In re Plantation Realty Trust
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, corporate veil may be pierced in order to impute liability among differing corporate entities: (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequence of that intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in a common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which the various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Headnote: Determination of whether two ostensibly separate business entities share common management, as part of inquiry into whether one is alter ego of the other, emphasizes common control over hiring and firing of employees as well as other daily management decisions.

Title: Conservatorship of Prom v. Sumitomo Rubber Industries, Ltd.

Headnote: Factors considered in determining if parent corporation controls subsidiary to such an extent that separate corporate identity of subsidiary should be disregarded are (1) common stock ownership, (2) overlapping directors and officers, (3) combined use of corporate offices, (4) capitalization of subsidiary by parent, (5) financing of subsidiary by parent, (6) control of subsidiary's stock by parent, (7) use of the subsidiary's property by parent, (8) intercorporate loans, (9) parental incorporation of subsidiary, (10) consolidated tax returns, (11) independent decision making by subsidiary, (12) independent decision making by directors of subsidiary, (13) observance of formal corporate legal requirements, (14) contracts between subsidiary and parent, and (15) fraud or injustice to third parties.

Title: Bostick v. Schall's Brakes and Repairs, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: To determine whether a successor corporation has been established as an "alter ego" of a former corporation and, thus, may be held liable for the former corporation's debts and liabilities, a court must analyze the following factors with respect to the two entities: (1) centralized control of labor relations; (2) common management; (3) interrelation of operations; and (4) common ownership and financial control.

Title: Hiller Cranberry Products, Inc. v. Koplovsky Foods, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: In determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, Massachusetts courts consider twelve factors: (1) common ownership; (2) pervasive control; (3) confused intermingling of business activity, assets or management; (4) insufficient capitalization for purposes of the corporate undertaking; (5) nonobservance of corporate formalities; (6) nonpayment of dividends; (7) insolvency of corporation at the time of the transaction; (8) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant shareholders; (9) nonfunctioning of officers and directors other than the shareholders; (10) absence of corporate records; (11) use of the corporation for transactions of the dominant shareholders; and (12) use of the corporation in promoting fraud.

Title: Olympic Financial Ltd. v. Consumer Credit Corp.

Title: F.D.I.C. v. Refco Group, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, factors that courts apply in deciding whether to disregard the separate nature of corporation and corporate subsidiary, not all of which must be present for corporate veil to be pierced, are: (1) whether parent corporation owns all or a majority of capital stock of subsidiary; (2) whether parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; (3) whether parent finances subsidiary; (4) whether parent subscribes to all the capital stock of subsidiary or otherwise causes its incorporation; (5) whether subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; (6) whether parent pays salaries or expenses or losses of subsidiary; (7) whether subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; (8) whether subsidiary' is referred to as such in papers of parent corporation and in statements of its officers; (9) whether directors or executives of subsidiary fail to act independently in interests of subsidiary; and (10) whether formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate and independent corporation are disregarded.

Title: NEC Technologies, Inc. v. Nelson

Title: National Soffit & Escutcheons, Inc. v. Superior Systems, Inc.

Title: Simplicity Pattern Co., Inc. v. Miami Tru-Color Off-Set Service, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Sublessee was mere instrumentality and alter ego of related corporation, as the latter dominated the affairs of the former, which domination caused wrong to sublessor by stopping payment of rent and breaching lease; there was an absence of formalities and paraphernalia of corporate existence of sublessee, it was inadequately capitalized, there was an overlap in ownership, officer, directors and personnel, there were common addresses and telephone numbers, sublessee's debts were paid by related corporation and related corporation used sublessee's property.
Document Preview: Corporate Veil. Dissolved corporate sublessee was mere instrumentality and alter-ego of related corporation.

Court: United States Court of Appeals, First Circuit.
Headnote: Maine law requires something more than overlap in corporations' directors for adversary of one corporation to pierce veil and reach the other.

Title: Brown v. Automotive Cas. Ins. Co.
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, First Circuit.
Headnote: Among factors that court considers in deciding whether two affiliated corporations may be regarded as a "single business enterprise" are: whether corporations have identity or substantial identity of ownership; common directors or officers; whether corporations share unified administrative control; intercorporate financing; inadequate capitalization; whether one corporation has caused incorporation of another affiliated corporation; one corporation's payment of salaries and other expenses or losses of another corporation; one corporation's receipt of business only from other corporation; corporations' use of each other's property; noncompliance with corporate formalities; common employees; common offices; centralized accounting; undocumented transfers of funds between corporations; unclear allocation of profits and losses between corporations; and whether there has been excessive fragmentation of single enterprise into separate corporations.
Document Preview: Liquidation. Casualty insurer and insurance premium finance company were a single business enterprise, all of whose assets could be administered by liquidator of insurer.

Title: Branch on Behalf of Maine Nat. Bank v. U.S.
Court: United States Court of Federal Claims.
Headnote: Corporations are treated as separate legal entities and are not responsible for debts of other corporations, even though they share common shareholders or officers.

Title: Select Creations, Inc. v. Paliafito America, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Circumstances which may be considered when deciding whether alter ego liability exists under California law include: identical equitable ownership in two entities; identification of equitable owners with dominion and control of two entities; use of same office of business location; employment of same employees and attorneys; use of corporation as mere shell, instrumentality, or conduit for single venture or business of individual or another corporation; concealment and misrepresentation of identity of responsible ownership, management, and financial interest; failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities; use of corporate entity to procure labor, services, or merchandise for another person or entity; and use of corporation as subterfuge for illegal transactions.

Title: Paglin v. Saztec Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Circumstances to consider under Missouri law in determining whether parent corporation "controls" subsidiary, for purposes of alter ego liability, are that parent owns all or most of subsidiary's capital stock; parent and subsidiary have common directors or officers; parent finances subsidiary; parent subscribes to all of subsidiary's capital stock or otherwise causes its incorporation; subsidiary has grossly inadequate capital; parent pays salaries and other expenses or losses of subsidiary; subsidiary has substantially no business except with parent or no assets except those conveyed to it by parent; in papers of parent or statements of its officers, subsidiary is described as department, division of parent, or its business or financial responsibility is referred to as parent's own; parent uses subsidiary's property as its own; subsidiary's directors or executives do not act independently in interest of subsidiary but take their orders from parent and the latter's interest; and formal legal requirements of subsidiary are not observed.

Title: Carte Blanche (Singapore) Pte., Ltd. v. Diners Club Intern., Inc.

Headnote: Subsidiary would not be treated as same entity as its parent, although 50% of subsidiary's stock was owned by parent and parent financed subsidiary's acquisition of equipment, some of which was used to haul material involved in subsidiary's action, where remainder of stock was owned by two directors who were not officers, directors or employees of parent and there was no showing that subsidiary had grossly inadequate capital, that parent had paid salaries, expenses or losses of subsidiary, that subsidiary was held out as division of parent, that president of subsidiary took orders from parent, or that formal legal requirements of subsidiary as separate corporation were not observed.

Title: Soanes v. Baltimore & O. R. Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E. D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, facts that there were interlocking directorates and executive officers between subsidiary and parent railroad corporation, that both accepted service at the same address, and that train master of subsidiary used business cards naming parent but not subsidiary did not warrant piercing the corporate veil, particularly in light of fact that subsidiary had its own employees, separate labor agreements, its own tax status, and several corporate directors who were unaffiliated with parent.

Headnote: Fact that one person controls two corporations is not sufficient to make two corporations and the controlling stockholder the same person under the law.

Headnote: Generally, courts will not because of stock ownership or interlocking directorship disregard the separate legal identities of corporations, unless such relationship is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrongs, such as violation of antitrust laws, protect fraud, or defend crime.

Title: Cornwell v. Williams Bros. Lumber Co.
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia, Division No. 3.

Title: Gentry v. Credit Plan Corp. of Houston
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: A subsidiary corporation will not be regarded as the alter ego of its parent merely because of stock ownership, because of duplication of some or all of the directors or officers, or because of exercise of control that stock ownership gives to the stockholders; on the other hand, where management and operations are assimilated to the extent that the subsidiary is simply a name or conduit through which the parent conducts its business, the corporate fiction may be disregarded to prevent fraud or injustice.

Title: Quarles v. Fuqua Industries, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Tenth Circuit.
Headnote: Facts that nonresident parent corporation received monthly financial reports from subsidiary and consulted with its officers, that parent provided financial support, that employment contracts of officers of subsidiary required them to be available in an advisory capacity to parent, that two of parent's staff members were on subsidiary's board of directors, that parent's employee stock purchase plan was available to employees of subsidiary, and that subsidiary was sold as an unprofitable investment did not warrant application of alter ego doctrine for jurisdiction over parent which, unlike subsidiary, had not engaged in any business transactions in the state, where total participation of parent in affairs of subsidiary did not amount to a domination of day to day business decisions of subsidiary. Fed.Rules Civ.Proc. rule 4(d)(7), (e), 28 U.S.C.A.; K.S.A. 60–308, 60–308(b).

Title: My Bread Baking Co. v. Cumberland Farms, Inc.
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Bristol.
Headnote: Although common stock ownership of corporations and common management alone will not make one corporation liable for acts of another, liability may be imposed upon one or more of group of closely identified corporations (a) when there is active and direct participation by representatives of one corporation, apparently exercising some form of pervasive control, in activities of another and there is some fraudulent or injurious consequences of intercorporate relationship, or (b) when there is confused intermingling of activity of two or more corporations engaged in common enterprise with substantial disregard of separate nature of corporate entities, or serious ambiguity about manner and capacity in which various corporations and their respective representatives are acting.

Title: Zaist v. Olson
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Essential purposes of corporate structure, including stockholder immunity, must and will be protected when corporation functions as entity in normal manner contemplated and permitted by law, and when it functions in such manner, there is nothing insidious in stockholder control, interlocking directorates, or identity of officers, but when corporation is so manipulated by individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for manipulator, justice may require courts to disregard corporate fiction and impose liability on real actor.
